[[Damian Elwes]] (brother) |spouse ={{marriage|Lisa Marie Kurbikoff|2000||}} |children = One daughter }} '''Ivan Simon Cary Elwes''' (born 26 October 1962),{{cite journal|title=World Almanac |work=[[Kent County Daily Times]]|date=26 October 2010|quote=Today's Birthdays: Cary Elwes (1962 -)}} known professionally as '''Cary Elwes''', is an English actor. The son of [[Dominick Elwes]] and [[Tessa Georgina Kennedy]], Elwes acted in [[off-Broadway]] plays during college and moved to the United States in the early 1980s. He is known for his role as Westley in the [[cult film|cult classic]] ''[[The Princess Bride (film)|The Princess Bride]]'' and for his role as Dr. [[Lawrence Gordon (character)|Lawrence Gordon]] in ''[[Saw (film)|Saw]]''. He has also appeared in box office successful films{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?id=caryelwes.htm|title=Cary Elwes Movie Box Office Results|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=27 September 2011}} such as ''[[Days of Thunder]]'', ''[[Hot Shots!]]'', ''[[Twister (1996 film)|Twister]]'', ''[[Liar, Liar]]'' and ''[[No Strings Attached (film)|No Strings Attached]]''. He has had [[Recurring character|recurring roles]] in television series such as ''[[The X-Files]]'' playing [[Brad Follmer]]. ==Early life and education== Elwes was born in [[Westminster]], London, and is the third and youngest son of portrait-painter [[Dominick Elwes]]{{cite journal|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20105004,00.html|title=A Hero to the Hilt|last=Cerio|first=Gregory|volume=43|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=6 February 1995|accessdate=26 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/61z6f7VsK|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no|issue=5}} and interior designer [[Tessa Kennedy|Tessa Georgina Kennedy]], who is of [[Croats|Croatian]] and [[Anglo-Irish]] descent. His paternal grandfather is painter [[Simon Elwes]],{{cite journal|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-3979412.html |first=Jae-Ha|last=Kim|title=British actor takes turn as American in 'Glory' {{subscription required}}|page=p. 25|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|publisher=[[Sun-Times Media Group]]| date=12 January 1990}} whose father was the diplomat and tenor [[Gervase Elwes]] (1866â1921).{{cite book|title=Loose Canon: A Portrait of Brian Brindley|url=http://books.google.com/?id=At3vy0eh2LUC&pg=PA134&dq=Gervase+Elwes+Simon#v=onepage&q=Gervase%20Elwes%20Simon&f=false|last=Thompson|first=Damian|authorlink=Damian Thompson|page=134|publisher=[[Continuum International Publishing Group|Continuum]]|isbn=0826474187|date=22 June 2004}} His brothers are [[Damian Elwes]], an artist, and [[Cassian Elwes]], a producer and agent. He is the stepson of [[Elliott Kastner]], an American film producer. One of his ancestors is [[John Elwes (politician)|John Elwes]], who is believed to be the inspiration for [[Ebenezer Scrooge]] in [[Charles Dickens]]' ''[[A Christmas Carol]]'' (1843).{{cite web|url=http://thecia.com.au/reviews/c/images/christmas-carol-production-notes.doc|title=''Disney's A Christmas Carol'' Production Notes|page=6|format=152KB [[DOC (computing)|.DOC]] file; [http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:uqqAzKJa3jUJ:thecia.com.au/reviews/c/images/christmas-carol-production-notes.doc HTML version]|publisher=Cinematic Intelligence Agency|date=21 October 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5tLrhTKfT|archivedate=9 October 2010|deadurl=no}} Elwes played the role of Dick Wilkins in the [[A Christmas Carol (2009 film)|2009 film adaptation]] of the novel. He was raised [[Roman Catholic]].{{cite web|last=Guthrie|first=Marisa|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2005/12/04/2005-12-04_the_spirit_moved_him.html|title=The spirit moved him|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|quote =Elwes, who grew up a Catholic,...|date=4 December 2005|accessdate=13 September 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/61zzNYuVF|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no}} Elwes attended [[Harrow School]] in London and [[London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art]].{{cite journal|title=Dr Gordon is back in Saw - Cary Elwes' character from the first Saw film is back by popular demand|work=[[The Straits Times]]|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]|date=5 January 2011}} Elwes moved to the [[United States]] in 1981 to study acting at [[Sarah Lawrence College]] in [[Bronxville, New York]].{{cite journal|title=The 'Robin' Who Has Sherwood Forest Chuckling|last=Tam Jr|first=Henry|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|page=C6|date=13 August 1993}} While living in New York, Elwes studied acting at both the [[Actors Studio]] and the [[Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute]]. ==Career== ===Film=== Elwes made his acting debut in 1984 with [[Marek Kanievska]]'s film ''[[Another Country (film)|Another Country]]''. He played James Harcourt, a young and sentimental homosexual student from an English [[boarding school]]. He went on to play [[Guilford Dudley]] in the British film ''[[Lady Jane (film)|Lady Jane]]'', co-starring [[Helena Bonham Carter]]. He was cast as a stable boy turned swashbuckler Westley in [[Rob Reiner]]'s fantasy-comedy ''[[The Princess Bride (film)|The Princess Bride]]'', based on the [[The Princess Bride|novel of the same name]] by [[William Goldman]]. It was a modest box office success,{{cite journal|title='The Princess Bride' Turns 20|journal=[[The Palm Beach Post]]|publisher=[[Cox Enterprises]]|page=6J|last=Gray Streeter|first=Leslie|date=9 December 2007|quote=[w]as a modest hit. But it became a raging cult classic after being released on video and shown on cable.}} but received critical acclaim, earning a score of 96% on the review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/princess_bride/|title=Prince Bride (1987)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Flixster]]|accessdate=2011 September 27}} Since being released on home video and television it has become a [[cult film|cult classic]]. In an interview around the film's DVD release in 2001, Elwes said, "The studio didn't know how to sell it - as an adventure, fantasy, comedy or love story, it had to rely on word of mouth". He also acknowledged the film's cult following saying, "Many people tell me they have it in their video collection, it's a family film but also a cult film in a way, being passed down to other generations".{{cite journal|title='Bride' basks in glow of video|journal=[[Houston Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|last=Westbrook|first=Bruce|date=6 September 2001}} [[File:CaryElwesApr10.jpg|thumb|left|Elwes in 2010.]] He continued working steadily, varying between dramatic roles, as in ''[[The Bride (film)|The Bride]]'' (1985) with [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] and [[Jennifer Beals]], to the [[Academy Award]]-winning ''[[Glory (1989 film)|Glory]]'' (1989), and comedic roles, as in ''[[Hot Shots!]]'' (1991). In 1993, he starred as [[Robin Hood]] in [[Mel Brooks]]' comedy, ''[[Robin Hood: Men in Tights]]''. Elwes also appeared in such films as [[Francis Coppola]]'s adaptation of ''[[Dracula (1992 film)|Bram Stoker's Dracula]]'', ''[[The Crush (1993 film)|The Crush]]'', ''[[Rudyard Kipling's The Jungle Book]]'', ''[[Twister (1996 film)|Twister]]'', ''[[Liar Liar]]'', ''[[Cradle Will Rock]]'', ''[[The Cat's Meow]]'' and ''[[Kiss the Girls (film)|Kiss the Girls]]''. In 2004, he starred in the [[Horror film|horror]]-[[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] ''[[Saw (film)|Saw]]'' which, at a budget of a little over $1 million, grossed over $100 million worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=saw.htm|title=Saw (2004)|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate={{nowrap|August 16, 2011}}}} ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' critic [[Owen Gleiberman]] gave him a negative review, describing his performance as [[overacting]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,734839,00.html|title=Saw Review|last=Gleiberman|first=Owen|authorlink=Owen Gleiberman|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=27 October 2004|accessdate=17 August 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6103ai5v8|archivedate=17 August 2011| deadurl=no}} The same year he appeared in ''[[Ella Enchanted (film)|Ella Enchanted]]'', portraying the villain rather than the hero. He made an uncredited appearance as Sam Green, the man who introduced [[Andy Warhol]] to [[Edie Sedgwick]], in the 2006 film ''[[Factory Girl]]''. In 2007, he appeared in [[Garry Marshall]]'s ''[[Georgia Rule]]'' with [[Jane Fonda]]. He also starred in the [[Mystery film|mystery]] [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] ''Shadows''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/17894|title=AFM '09: Carey Elwes in 'Shadows', First It is awaiting release.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/adelaide-clemens-gregg-sulkin-cary-43460|title=Exclusive: Four Actors Board Madeleine L'Engle Adaptation|last=Kit|first=Borys|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=9 November 2010|accessdate=26 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/620D88kV0|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no}} In 2012, Elwes will appear in the independent drama ''[[The Citizen (film)|The Citizen]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118039848|title=4 thesps apply for 'The Citizen'|last=Sneider|first=Jeff|work=Variety|publisher=Reed Business Information|date=13 July 2011|accessdate=26 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/620GcKyyS|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no}} [[File:Cary Elwes Saw 3D premiere cropped.jpg|thumb|right|Elwes attending a premiere of ''Saw 3D'']] On 23 October 2011, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported that Elwes will make his directorial debut with an independent film, ''[[Elvis & Nixon]]''. [[Eric Bana]] and [[Danny Huston]] signed on to portray [[Elvis Presley]] and [[Richard Nixon]], respectively. Elwes wrote the script with [[Joey Sagal]] and [[Hanala Sagal]], which is "inspired by a true historical event". Michael Benaroya will finance the film (through Benaroya Pictures) and will be shot in [[Los Angeles]] and [[Shreveport, Louisiana]] at an unspecified date.{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118044904|title=Bana to rock & role in 'Elvis & Nixon' |last=Sneider|first=Jeff|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Reed Business Information]]|date=23 October 2011|accessdate=24 October 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/62fZxwO8F|archivedate=24 October 2011|deadurl=no}} ===Television=== In 1996, Elwes made his first television appearance as David Lookner on the sitcom ''[[Seinfeld]]''. In 1998, he played astronaut [[Michael Collins (astronaut)|Michael Collins]] in the [[Golden Globe Award]]-winning [[HBO]] [[miniseries]] ''[[From the Earth to the Moon (miniseries)|From the Earth To the Moon]]''. In 1999, he guest starred as Dr. John York in an episode of the television series ''[[The Outer Limits (1995 TV series)|The Outer Limits]]''. He earned two [[Satellite Awards|Golden Satellite Award]] nominations for his performances in the television films ''[[The Pentagon Wars]]'' and ''[[Uprising (film)|Uprising]]''. Elwes had a recurring role in the final season (from 2001 to 2002) of ''[[The X-Files]]'' as [[FBI Assistant Director]] [[Brad Follmer]]. In 2004, he played serial killer [[Ted Bundy]] in the [[A&E Network]] television film ''The Riverman'', which was based on the book ''[[The Riverman: Ted Bundy and I Hunt for the Green River Killer]]'' written by [[Robert D. Keppel]]. In 2005, Elwes played the young [[Pope John Paul II]] in the [[CBS]] television film ''[[Pope John Paul II (film)|Pope John Paul II]]''. In 2007, he made a guest appearance on the ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' episode "[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (season 8)#ep14|Dependent]]" as a [[Mafia]] lawyer. In 2009, he played the role of Pierre Despereaux, an international art thief, in the fourth season premiere of ''[[Psych]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/35164/first-two-teaser-clips-psych-9|title=First Two Teaser Clips Psych: 9|work=DreadCentral|publisher=[[CraveOnline]]|date=2 January 2010|accessdate=26 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/620BPhle9|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no}} In 2010, he returned to ''[[Psych]]'', reprising his role in the second half of the fifth season. He will guest star again in the show's [[Psych (season 6)|sixth season]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tvline.com/2011/07/psych-spoiler-video-season-6-james-roday-dule-hill/|title=Psych First Look: The Season 6 Scene Everyone Will Be Talking About! Plus, Musical Update!|last=Slezak|first=Michael|work=[[TVLine]]|publisher=[[PMC (company)|PMC]]|date=21 July 2011|accessdate=27 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/620HTJJfL|archivedate=27 September 2011|deadurl=no}} In March 2011, Elwes was selected to appear as Henry Detmer in the pilot episode of [[NBC]]'s ''[[Cultural impact of Wonder Woman#NBC pilot (2011)|Wonder Woman]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/03/cary-elwes-joins-nbcs-wonder-woman/|title=Cary Elwes Joins NBC's 'Wonder Woman'|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|work=[[Deadline.com]]|publisher=PMC|date=4 March 2011|accessdate=26 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/620B3NYSM|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no}} However, the show was never picked up for a series.{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/05/12/nbc-rejects-wonder-woman/|title=NBC rejects 'Wonder Woman'|last= Rice|first=Lynette|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=12 May 2011|accessdate=26 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/620B7uApH|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no}} ===Voiceovers=== Elwes' [[voice-over]] work includes the narrator in [[James Patterson]]'s audio book ''The Jester'',{{cite book|title=The Jester|last=Paterson|first=James|authorlink=James Patterson|last2=Gross|first2=Andrew|authorlink2=Andrew Gross|isbn=1-58621-535-3 |publisher=[[Hachette Audio]]| edition=Abridged|date=1 March 2003}} as well as characters in film and television animations such as ''[[Quest for Camelot]]'', ''[[Pinky and The Brain]]'', ''[[Batman Beyond]]'', and the English versions of the [[Studio Ghibli]] films ''[[Porco Rosso]]'', ''[[Whisper of the Heart (film)|Whisper of the Heart]]'' and ''[[The Cat Returns]]''. For the 2004 video game ''[[The Bard's Tale (2004)|The Bard's Tale]]'', he served as scriptwriter, improviser, and [[voice acting|voice actor]] of the main character The Bard. In 2011, Elwes performed the English voice over for Indian film, ''[[Delhi Safari]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/2011/05/30/15833/index.html|title=Delhi Safari to feature voiceover by Vanessa Williams and Jason Alexander|work=[[Bollywood Hungama]]|date=30 May 2011|accessdate=26 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/620CPeGXA|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no}} He appeared in [[Robert Zemeckis]]'s [[motion capture]] adaption of ''A Christmas Carol'', which was released to mixed reviews. Elwes will appear in [[Steven Spielberg]]'s adaption of Belgian artist [[HergÃ©]]'s popular comic strip ''[[The Adventures of Tintin (film)|The Adventures of Tintin]]''. ===Theatre=== While still in college in the 1980s, Elwes acted in [[off-Broadway]] plays. In 2003 he performed in [[Bob Balaban]]-directed [[Off-Broadway]] dramatic stage play ''[[The Exonerated]]'' in New York during its March 18â23, week run.{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/78481-Cary-Elwes-and-Brooke-Shields-Join-Off-Broadways-Exonerated-March-18-23|title=Cary Elwes and Brooke Shields Join Off-Broadway's Exonerated, March 18-23|last=Hernandez|first=Ernio|work=[[Playbill]]|date=18 March 2003|accessdate=27 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/620HfyaXS|archivedate=27 September 2011|deadurl=no}} ==Personal life== Elwes met [[unit still photographer|still photographer]] Lisa Marie Kurbikoff in 1991 at a [[Malibu, Baja California|Malibu]] [[Cook-off#Chili cook-off|chili cook-off]] and became engaged in 1997.{{cite journal|title=Celebrities - Degeneres 'Bedding' Talk-Show Guests|work=[[Watertown Daily Times]]|date=3 May 2007|page=D2|quote=Elwes and Lisa Marie (nee Kurbikoff ) met in 1991 at a Malibu chili cook-off. They were engaged in 1997 and tied the knot three years later.}} They married in 2000 and have one child together, a daughter named Dominique born on 24 April 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20037158,00.html|title=Cary Elwes, Wife Welcome a Girl|last=Silverman|first=Stephen M.|last2=Jordan|first2=Julie|work=People|publisher=Time Inc.|date=27 April 2007|accessdate=26 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/61zBZ2eeX|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no}} In August 2005, Elwes filed a lawsuit against [[Evolution Entertainment]], his management firm and producer of ''Saw''. He said he was promised a minimum of one per cent of the producers' net profits of the film and did not receive the full amount.{{cite news |title=Not everyone happy with their cut from Saw |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/film/not-everyone-happy-with-their-cut-from-saw/2005/08/20/1124435169494.html|last=Mitchell|first=Peter|agency=[[Association of American Publishers|AAP]]|work=[[The Age]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|date=20 August 2005|accessdate=26 September 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/61z597QPB|archivedate=26 September 2011|deadurl=no}} The case eventually [[legal settlement|settled out of court]].
